nodes.bodyText: I've moved this class to core. It seemed silly to duplicate it when it was generally useful.
add an empty private constructor
this can be static too

The idea is that it would probably be configurable, it's just a placeholder for now.
(Maybe it shouldn't be configurable, I was just sketching something out as I went).

I think it would make sense to have a setting on the IDP side that controls the assertion lifetime and maybe allow sp specific configuration overrides. I can't think of a valid reason or use case to extend the lifetime for specific SPs though

Since this is just an interface, how we resolve the duration per SP isn't dictated, just that the Response builder doesn't assume it's a global value in the IdP.
For things that could reasonably be set per SP (that is, there's no technical reason why it should be fixed for the IdP), I'd prefer to provide them to on the SP so that the Builder doesn't make assumptions.
One reason I can think of for having a per-SP duration is if the SP doesn't properly handle clock skew so you need to increase the expiry time specifically for that SP.
nitpicking much but I prefer URNs as folks tend to treat ^^ as URLs instead of URIs
I'm sure we'll change it, I just needed a value from somewhere, and didn't want to hard code it inside the Response Builder (and the valid syntax for the https scheme is easier to remember than urn).

In the case where user.getGroups() returns an empty set/list, this will produce an Attribute node with no AttributeValue . While the specificatio 2.7.3.1 allows for Attributes without values, the semantics are left to the implementer. I would argue that for an attribute that denotes group membership, the presence or absence of the attribute is of no interest to an SP, they would only care about its values. As such, I suggest we do not send the attribute at all.
Our SP implementation will handle an attribute with no values gracefully, but I'm not sure all SPs will

If we don't create an empty attribute for no values ( see above ) then we should not add an AttributeStatement to the Assertion either, because the assertion schema has
<choice maxOccurs="unbounded">
  <element ref="saml:Attribute"/>
  <element ref="saml:EncryptedAttribute"/>
</choice>

which , in absence of an explicit minOccurs, inherits the default value of 1

I think we should allow for per SP configuration ( not direct feedback for this PR ) and that we should default to transient NameIDs ( so that we can have logout ) and the principal expressed as an attribute. I believe this buys us maximum interoperability (it usually is easier to map an attribute than the NameID value on the SP side )
Yes, I suspect that's probably what we want (but also that generating transient nameids was more trouble than I wanted to go to for the first cut of code).
see comment about default lifetime being expressed as an idp configuration

set NameFormat to urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:attrname-format:uri
attribute.setNameFormat(Attribute.URI_REFERENCE);
Do you think we can enforce that we only use URIs for attribute names? It's my preference, but it seems most popular IdPs don't.
It's up to the IDP so I think we should do it ( my preference too )

We would probably need an instance of DocumentBuilderFactory when parsing authentication requests, we could switch to using that at that point. Is it worth adding a comment that this should be used in tests only ?
We may want this in production if we accept metadata from SPs, but I'm happy to move it to test and move it back again if we do find we need it.

Since we get to do the naming here (yay), should we settle to something different than groups ? I'm torn as it "makes sense" for our SP implementation (see attributes.groups: ) but as an IDP, will the information that we will encode here denote groups or rather roles ?

Yeah, I was torn on this. They're not really groups, but roles is so over used that I think it will become confusing.
From an ES point of view they'll probably be something related to application privileges.
So, from that position they're privileges, but I'm not sure whether exposing that name here is right...
We can defer the decision to a later point I guess
The Assertion must contain an <AuthnStatement> (  and that should contain a SessionIndex since we plan to support SLO )
Why didn't the schema pick me up on that... :(
This is a requirement for the Web browser SSO profile so it's not covered by the Assertion schema
Ah, because Saml2Int expects it (as do we) but the schema doesn't.

Not that it matters too much but it's not saml2int but the actual OASIS standard 4.1.4.2. Only mentioning as it can be argued that saml2int is not mandatory to follow ( but rather a choice ), but the actual spec is.

subject should contain an <SubjectConfirmation> with

a Method set to urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:cm:bearer
a <SubjectConfirmationData> element with:

a Recipient attribute pointing to the SP ACS
a NotOnOrAfter
an InResponseTo with the request ID ( if this is SP initiated )
We should also add a SessionIndex ( with the same value as the Assertion ID see 2.7.2

Sorry, it was late when I finished up so I didn't comment.
I agree we'll need one for SLO, but since we're not doing SLO yet, I intentionally left it out so that whoever implements SLO can do it end-to-end.
That's on the assumption that there's nothing in the standard that requires a SessionIndex (I didn't see anything).
we should aim so that we will never have to use such a declaration
I expect that everything will be over TLS, but I didn't want to assume that in the code.
I've assumed Password + IP Filter should be treated as a higher class than Password + TLS, but ideally there would be a class for IP_PPT_AUTHN_CTX  instead.
